metadata.titleEn: A daily, 0.05° Snow depth dataset for Tibetan Plateau (2000-2018)
metadata.description:
Under the funding of the first project (Development of Multi-scale Observation and Data Products of Key Cryosphere Parameters) of the National Key Research and Development Program of China-"The Observation and Inversion of Key Parameters of Cryosphere and Polar Environmental Changes", the research group of Zhang, Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, developed the snow depth downscaling product in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. The snow depth downscaling data set for the Tibetan Plateau is derived from the fusion of snow cover probability dataset and Long-term snow depth dataset in China. The sub-pixel spatio-temporal downscaling algorithm is developed to downscale the original 0.25° snow depth dataset, and the 0.05° daily snow depth product is obtained. By comparing the accuracy evaluation of the snow depth product before and after downscaling, it is found that the root mean square error of the snow depth downscaling product is 0.61 cm less than the original product. 
     The details of the product information of the Downscaling of Snow Depth Dataset for the Tibetan Plateau (2000-2018) are as follows. The projection is longitude and latitude, the spatial resolution is 0.05° (about 5km), and the time is from September 1, 2000 to September 1, 2018. It is a TIF format file. The naming rule is SD_yyyyddd.tif, where yyyy represents year and DDD represents Julian day (001-365). Snow depth (SD), unit: centimeter (cm). The spatial resolution is 0.05°. The time resolution is day by day.

background: Accurate remotely sensed snow depth (SD) data are essential for monitoring and modeling hydrological processes in cold regions. While the available passive microwave SD data have been widely used by the community, the coarse spatial resolution (typically at 0.25°) of these data impedes the explicit representation of the hydrological processes in snow-dominated regions, especially in mountainous regions with complex terrain. Snow is a key component of the hydrological cycle and an important indicator of climate change. It also plays a key role in the energy balance because of its strong effect on the surface albedo and soil temperature, thereby modulating the local and regional weather and climate. The snowpack can store a large amount of the precipitation that falls during the cold season, it also plays a vital role in the spring runoff formulation, impacting the downstream agricultural production, which relies on irrigation. The snow depth (SD) is the most important variable that describes the amount of snow for a given region. Several approaches have been extensively used to monitor the SD, including field observations, land surface modeling, optical remote sensing, and passive microwave remote sensing.
research objective: To improve the spatial resolution and quality of passive microwave SD data for the Tibetan Plateau (TP), we develop a spatial-temporal downscaling method to produce a 19-year, daily 0.05° SD product by combining the existing high temporal resolution daily SD data and the high spatial resolution 8-day cloud-free Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)-based snow cover probability (SCP) data. The objectives of this study are (i) to develop a spatiotemporal downscaling method by taking advantage of the spatial information of the MODIS SCP and the temporal information of the passive microwave SD during an 8-day period to produce a finer resolution (i.e., 0.05°) SD product across the TP; (ii) to determine whether the accuracy of this newly-developed 0.05° SD product is better than that of the previous coarse-resolution SD dataset; and (iii) to investigate the spatial and temporal variations in SD over TP during the last two decades.
challenges: The coarse spatial resolution of such SD products is not adequate for hydrological modeling studies in small watersheds where the runoff is often simulated at the kilometer scale. The development of high-resolution (both spatially and temporally) remote sensing SD data in the Tibetan Plateau is challenging because of its heterogeneous landscape and scarce ground observations. Although the SD dataset was improved, with a better resolution of 0.05°, the error of the representativeness is inevitable when validating pixel-based SD products based on ground-based SD measurements.
methods: The ratio of the sum of the fractional snow cover (FSC sum) data to the sum of the clear index (CI sum) data during a period is an improved method for estimating the spatial probability of the snow cover, which makes full use of the snow cover and cloud information from the original MODIS snow product. The new advanced SCP dataset was generated by combining MODIS Terra and Aqua data for 2002–2018 at a spatial resolution of 0.05° over the entire TP. If the pixel was completely (100%) covered by clouds during the entire 8-day period, the spatial probability of snow cover was estimated using the cloud-free spatial probability of snow cover for the preceding 8-day period (PSCP) and that of the following 8-day period (FSCP). Using the ratio of daily SD to the 8-day SD sum, the daily temporal weight can be calculated to improve the temporal resolution of the 8-day SD sum dataset containing subpixel spatial information.
dataset: The MODIS snow cover data version 006 from 2000 to 2018 from the Terra (MOD10C1) and Aqua (MYD10C1) satellites were downloaded (accessible from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), http://nsidc.org). The long-term daily, 0.25° SD dataset from 2000 to 2018 was downloaded from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (https://data.tpdc.ac.cn/zh-hans/). The daily SD data during 2000-2010 observed at 92 meteorological stations of the China Meteorological Administration were used as the “ground-truth” values for assessing the accuracy of the gridded SD product.
findings: Validations against the observed SD data from 92 meteorological stations suggest that the newly-developed 0.05° SD product greatly improves upon the original 0.25° version. Based on this 0.05° SD product, we found that higher SD values are mainly distributed on the southeastern and eastern TP as well as the Himalaya and Karakoram, while much lower SD values occur on the inner TP. During 2000–2018, the TP-averaged annual SD showed a slight (p > 0.05) increasing trend because there were little changes in SD for most grids across the TP. The newly-developed 0.05° SD product could facilitate our understanding of the hydrological processes on the TP through a more explicit representation of the gridded-based snow water information.

Feature Specification.Answer: remotely sensed passive microwave SD data, MODIS-based snow cover probability data, spatial resolution from 0.25° to 0.05°, daily high temporal resolution SD data, 8-day cloud-free MODIS snow cover probability data

Definition.Question: What is a spatial-temporal downscaling method in the context of snow depth data collection?
Definition.Answer: A spatial-temporal downscaling method is a technique used to improve the spatial and temporal resolution of snow depth (SD) data by combining high temporal resolution daily SD data with high spatial resolution 8-day cloud-free Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)-based snow cover probability (SCP) data, allowing for the creation of a finer resolution SD product.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with developing high-resolution remote sensing snow depth data in mountainous regions?
Definition.Answer: Developing high-resolution remote sensing snow depth data in mountainous regions, such as the Tibetan Plateau, is challenging due to the heterogeneous landscape and the scarcity of ground observations, which affects the accuracy and representativeness when validating pixel-based SD products with ground-based measurements.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection techniques between the MODIS-based snow cover probability data and the passive microwave SD data in terms of their spatial and temporal resolution?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS-based snow cover probability data provide high spatial resolution information at 0.05° over an 8-day period, whereas passive microwave SD data offer a coarser spatial resolution at 0.25° but with high temporal resolution on a daily basis. The combination of these datasets leverages both high spatial and temporal resolutions.

Comparison.Question: How do the validation methods using meteorological station data compare with pixel-based SD product validations in terms of error reduction for the new 0.05° SD dataset?
Comparison.Answer: Validation methods using meteorological station data help assess the accuracy of the new 0.05° SD dataset, resulting in reduced error compared to the original product. However, pixel-based SD product validations still face representativeness challenges due to the heterogeneous landscape and the spatial resolution mismatch with ground measurements.

Interpretation.Question: How can spatial-temporal downscaling methods be improved to enhance the accuracy of snow depth datasets in regions with complex terrain?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial-temporal downscaling method can be improved by taking advantage of both high temporal resolution data and high spatial resolution data, as demonstrated by combining daily snow depth data with 8-day cloud-free MODIS-based snow cover probability data. This approach leverages the spatial information from MODIS and the temporal information from passive microwave snow depth data to produce finer resolution datasets.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise when validating pixel-based snow depth datasets using ground-based measurements, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include the error of representativeness when validating pixel-based snow depth datasets with ground-based measurements due to heterogeneous landscapes and scarce observations. These challenges might be addressed by improving the resolution of datasets, as seen with the development of a 0.05° snow depth product, which showed reduced errors compared to previous coarse-resolution datasets.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the development of high-resolution remote sensing snow depth data particularly challenging for the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development of high-resolution remote sensing snow depth data for the Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to its heterogeneous landscape and the scarcity of ground observations. These factors contribute to difficulties in accurately validating pixel-based snow depth products with ground-based measurements, leading to representativeness errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need to utilize both MODIS Terra and Aqua data for generating the snow cover probability dataset over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The use of both MODIS Terra and Aqua data is necessary to generate a snow cover probability dataset because it allows for the combination of data to fill gaps caused by cloud cover, ensuring a more complete and accurate representation of snow cover probability at a spatial resolution of 0.05° over the entire Tibetan Plateau. This approach improves the estimation by utilizing the cloud-free spatial probability of snow cover from adjacent periods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a spatial-temporal downscaling method on the accuracy of snow depth datasets in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The potential consequence of using a spatial-temporal downscaling method is an improvement in the spatial resolution and quality of snow depth datasets, which can lead to a more accurate representation of hydrological processes in snow-dominated regions, especially in complex terrains like mountainous areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of validating pixel-based snow depth products using ground-based measurements in terms of dataset accuracy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Validating pixel-based snow depth products using ground-based measurements can lead to challenges in representativeness, as errors in the dataset are inevitable. However, this validation approach is crucial for assessing and improving the accuracy of snow depth products by providing 'ground-truth' values that help refine dataset precision.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to improve the spatial resolution and quality of snow depth data for the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Improving the spatial resolution and quality of snow depth data for the Tibetan Plateau is crucial because accurate remotely sensed snow depth data are essential for monitoring and modeling hydrological processes in cold regions. The existing passive microwave snow depth data have a coarse spatial resolution, which impedes the explicit representation of hydrological processes, particularly in mountainous regions with complex terrain. High-resolution data are needed for effective hydrological modeling, especially in small watersheds where runoff is often simulated at the kilometer scale.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind developing a spatiotemporal downscaling method for snow depth data in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives behind developing a spatiotemporal downscaling method for snow depth data in the Tibetan Plateau include: (i) producing a finer resolution (0.05°) snow depth product by combining high temporal resolution daily snow depth data with high spatial resolution 8-day cloud-free Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)-based snow cover probability data; (ii) improving the accuracy compared to previous coarse-resolution datasets; and (iii) investigating the spatial and temporal variations in snow depth over the Tibetan Plateau during the last two decades.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the challenges associated with developing high-resolution remote sensing snow depth data for the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The challenges associated with developing high-resolution remote sensing snow depth data for the Tibetan Plateau include the heterogeneous landscape and scarce ground observations, which complicate the creation of accurate datasets. Additionally, while improved resolution of 0.05° was achieved, there remains an inevitable error of representativeness when validating pixel-based snow depth products with ground-based measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in developing a spatial-temporal downscaling method to improve the spatial resolution of passive microwave snow depth data for a region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To develop a spatial-temporal downscaling method, the approach involves combining high temporal resolution daily snow depth data with high spatial resolution 8-day cloud-free MODIS-based snow cover probability data. This method takes advantage of the spatial information of MODIS snow cover probability and the temporal information of passive microwave snow depth over an 8-day period to produce a finer resolution snow depth product.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the accuracy of a newly-developed high-resolution snow depth dataset be evaluated using ground-based measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy of a high-resolution snow depth dataset can be evaluated by comparing it against ground-truth snow depth data observed at meteorological stations. In the context provided, the daily snow depth data observed at 92 meteorological stations of the China Meteorological Administration were used to assess the accuracy of the gridded snow depth product, helping to validate the improvement upon the original coarse-resolution dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What techniques are used to estimate snow cover probability in regions with persistent cloud cover when developing snow depth datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In regions with persistent cloud cover, the spatial probability of snow cover can be estimated by using the cloud-free spatial probability of snow cover from preceding and following periods. This is achieved by calculating the ratio of the sum of fractional snow cover data to the sum of clear index data during an 8-day period, which makes full use of the snow cover and cloud information from MODIS snow product data.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the improvement of spatial resolution in snow depth datasets over complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The improvement of spatial resolution in snow depth datasets is enabled by a spatial-temporal downscaling method that combines the high temporal resolution of passive microwave snow depth data with the high spatial resolution of 8-day cloud-free MODIS-based snow cover probability data.

Enablement.Question: How do advanced data collection techniques address the challenges of representing hydrological processes in snow-dominated regions with heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Advanced data collection techniques utilize the ratio of fractional snow cover data to the clear index data, making full use of snow cover and cloud information from MODIS products. This method allows for better representation of hydrological processes by improving spatial probability estimates of snow cover.

Enablement.Question: What resources are necessary for validating high-resolution snow depth products at the pixel level when ground observations are scarce?
Enablement.Answer: Validating high-resolution snow depth products requires the use of daily snow depth data observed at meteorological stations as ground-truth values. These are crucial for assessing the accuracy of gridded snow depth products, especially in regions like the Tibetan Plateau where ground observations are limited.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset for snow depth in mountainous regions struggle to achieve high spatial resolution despite technological advancements?
Expectation.Answer: The coarse spatial resolution of snow depth products is challenging due to the heterogeneous landscape and scarce ground observations in mountainous regions, which makes it difficult to achieve high resolution necessary for detailed hydrological modeling.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated benefits of using a spatial-temporal downscaling method for snow depth data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: A spatial-temporal downscaling method can improve the spatial resolution and quality of passive microwave snow depth data, providing a finer resolution product that better represents the hydrological processes over the Tibetan Plateau, potentially enhancing understanding of snow water information and hydrological processes.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the spatial-temporal downscaling method used for improving snow depth data accuracy in cold regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The spatial-temporal downscaling method is considered effective as it significantly enhances the spatial resolution of snow depth data from 0.25° to 0.05°, reducing the root mean square error from 2.15 cm to 1.54 cm, thereby improving the accuracy of the snow depth product for the Tibetan Plateau.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges and limitations in using remotely sensed data for hydrological modeling in mountainous regions with complex terrain?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include the coarse spatial resolution of existing snow depth products, which is inadequate for small watershed modeling, and the heterogeneous landscape of mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau, which complicates accurate snow depth estimation due to scarce ground observations.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the integration of ground-based measurements enhance the accuracy and validation of gridded snow depth products?
Judgmental.Answer: Integration of ground-based measurements, such as those observed at meteorological stations, provides 'ground-truth' values that are essential for assessing and improving the accuracy of gridded snow depth products, helping to address errors in representativeness when validating pixel-based SD products.

Assertion.Question: I'm puzzled about how the spatial probability of snow cover is determined when cloud coverage is extensive over a period.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial probability of snow cover during periods of extensive cloud coverage is estimated using the cloud-free spatial probability of snow cover from the preceding and following 8-day periods. This method makes full use of the snow cover and cloud information from the original MODIS snow product.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how combining different data sources can enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of snow depth datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Combining high temporal resolution passive microwave snow depth data with high spatial resolution MODIS-based snow cover probability data allows for the development of a spatial-temporal downscaling method that improves the resolution of snow depth products to 0.05°, providing finer detail for hydrological studies.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges posed by using coarse spatial resolution data for hydrological modeling in small watersheds.
Assertion.Answer: Coarse spatial resolution snow depth products are inadequate for hydrological modeling in small watersheds because runoff is often simulated at a kilometer scale, necessitating higher resolution data to accurately represent hydrological processes in regions with complex terrain.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used to improve the spatial resolution of snow depth data for complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The spatial resolution of snow depth data for the Tibetan Plateau was improved by developing a spatial-temporal downscaling method. This involved combining high temporal resolution daily snow depth data with high spatial resolution 8-day cloud-free MODIS-based snow cover probability data. The method utilized the ratio of the sum of fractional snow cover data to the sum of clear index data to estimate the spatial probability of snow cover, taking full advantage of MODIS Terra and Aqua data from 2002 to 2018.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in developing high-resolution snow depth datasets in mountainous regions with scarce ground observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Developing high-resolution snow depth datasets in mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to its heterogeneous landscape and limited availability of ground observations. Although the spatial resolution was improved to 0.05°, validating pixel-based snow depth products based on ground-based measurements remains an issue due to representativeness errors. The challenge is compounded by the need for accurate hydrological modeling studies in small watersheds where runoff is simulated at the kilometer scale.
